page.title: 13THE VILLAGE OF HARGRAVE
page.content: Hargrave is a village three miles east of Raunds. It is on the borders of Northamptonshire,Bedfordshire and Cambridgeshire.It has a population of approximately 250 people. Hargrave has two roads leading to it, the main A45 road and a by-road. The village is set in a low valley about 80 metres above sea level.The soil is Oxford Clay and is rather chalky. The water supply comes from Raunds and from Bedfordshire. Electricity first came to village in 1949. There are no schools in Hargrave so the occupants have to go to Dean, Kimbolton, Raunds or Wellingborough. There are no shops or recreation areas but there are a lot of woods and spinneys suitable for walking anbd exploring. The name Hargrave means "army camp" and it is believed there was a roman camp there.
